data.title: Sancta Nomina
data.meta_description: Posts about Camp Patton written by sanctanomina
data.text:
Happy Lundi Gras (Mardi Grasâ€™ little-known sister)! ğŸ˜‚ Of course by the time you read this it probably *will* be Mardi Gras, since itâ€™s taken me allll dayyyy to get this up due to my little stinker Luke who refused to nap.

Iâ€™m super excited to share my predictions for our buddy Grace Pattonâ€™s new baby, due in June!! Iâ€™m calling them predictions rather than suggestions since Iâ€™ve previously done two consultations for Grace (here and here), and been so surprised by the names she and her hubby ended up giving the babies (which is something I LOVE â€“ being surprised by names never ceases to thrill me!) â€¦ so I feel like I donâ€™t really have anything to offer the Pattons! They are Baby Naming Royalty, as far as Iâ€™m concerned, and I canâ€™t wait to hear what they name this little green bean! (=gender unknown ğŸŒ±) (I posted birth announcements for babies five, six, and seven as well.)

But of course I canâ€™t stop my namey head from trying to get in their headspace and predict what names, or kinds of names?, they might choose! So first off, as a refresher, Babyâ€™s big brothers and sisters are:

Julia Grace

Sebastian Xavier (Bash)

Theodore Augustine (Theo)

Phoebe Anika

Bosco Ignatius

Abraham James (Abe)

Clement Joseph

+FelipÃ© (with Jesus)

Amazing names, each one! â¤ â¤ â¤ I did chat with Grace a little bit recently about names for this baby-on-the-way, and she said,

â€œWe really are kind of coming up empty-handed, honestly! We feel like we are completely out of boy names (of course we arenâ€™t â€” just will take some digging/thinking â€” and Simon prefers to chat about names on the way to the hospital, ha!) and understand why my mom used one of my brotherâ€™s middle names as a first name (Daniel Peter and then Peter Joseph when she had her fourth boy). So, Iâ€™d love suggestions or predictions! Phoebe (at the mature age of 5) is really concerned that any potential girl names, â€œsound nice with Phoebe and Juliaâ€ and so far all she has approved is, â€œCatherineâ€ â€” ha! I do love that name but I wouldnâ€™t consider it a frontrunner at the moment.

Because Juliaâ€™s middle name is Grace and Phoebeâ€™s middle name is Anika (which means grace) â€” Simon loves the idea of carrying the tradition on with another middle girl name that also means grace â€” which I feel less strongly about but am not at all opposed to the sentiment!

If Clement wasnâ€™t Clement I think he wouldâ€™ve been a Dominic but again, not a frontrunner this time around â€” funny how that works! Sebastian wouldâ€™ve been a Vivienne had he been a girl and I think Abe was going to be Iris if he was a girl and I still love those names but I donâ€™t know â€” we still have months to discuss, I suppose!â€

Such good info here! I love that Phoebe is concerned that a sisterâ€™s name â€œsound nice with Phoebe and Juliaâ€ â€” I definitely took that to heart when coming up with my list of predictions! (For the record, one of the things I love about her idea of Catherine is that it ends in a different sound than Julia and Phoebe â€” not so easy to do with girl names, since ends-in-a and ends-in-the-ee-sound are pretty common! Youâ€™ll see I included some other differently-ending-names below.)

So we know that Vivienne and Iris were previous frontrunners for a girl, as well as Dominic for a boy. I remember from my previous Patton posts that Caroline and Felicity were also previously discussed, as well as Damian and Simon Jr. (yes, even for a non-firstborn); also no more ends-in-o names for boys either (because of Theo and Bosco).

Since I did two previous consultations, there are a lottttt of names that Iâ€™ve already suggested, like:

Various ideas for backing into the nickname Lola (Violet, Caroline, Lourdes, Louisa, Lucia)

Elisabeth

Felicity

Stella

Emmeline

Magdalene

Verity

Audrey

A bunch of Mary/Maria/Marie+ ideas (any of those paired with Olivia or Olive, Ophelia, Simone, Tess, Elliott, Emmett, Bennett)

Maximilian nicked Miles

Francis nicked Finn

Gregory nicked Rory or Gus [Gregory Simon=Gus so perfectly!]

Oliver

Isaac

Gabriel

Alexander

Nathaniel

(As you can see, there were a couple instances of overlap between names Iâ€™d suggested and names they considered! SO exciting!)

There were several that Iâ€™d considered that didnâ€™t end up making my final cut, but I think a lot of these still potentially have merit (Graceâ€™s previous idea of Iris is on here! Woo!):

Penelope

Imogen(e)

Genevieve

Iris or Ivy

Lydia (in BOTH previous consultations)

Corinne

Liv

Alice

Zara

Natalia

Tobias (too much long O probably)

Tristan

Benedict/Bennett and Benjamin

Matthias

Samuel

Henry

Elliott

Emmett

Jude

Whew! This post is a study in New Evangelization Catholic Baby Naming! ğŸ’ƒ ğŸ’ƒ ğŸ’ƒ What names are left??

I was actually chuckling as I was pulling this post together, because when I do repeat consultations (or â€œpredictions posts,â€ as Iâ€™m calling this one), I always start from scratch, without looking back at my previous ideas. Then Iâ€™ll go back and cross off any repeats. When I did so here, it was hilarious to discover that there were SO MANY names I had to cross off of my ideas below! So many that I thought were spot on, but Iâ€™d already suggested them previously! (As usual, I looked up the names theyâ€™ve already used in the Baby Name Wizard, and I looked through my book of Marian baby names; I also used the Name Matchmaker tool on babynamewizard.com, and spent a bit of time looking for names that mean â€œgrace.â€ I also looked through a bunch of recent Appellation Mountain posts that list the names that are big on the site that week â€” Iâ€™ve always thought Grace has her finger on â€œthe pulse,â€ and up-and-coming names would be right in her wheelhouse I think.) After whittling my list down to just new ideas, these are the names that I think Grace and Simon might consider (with, okay, an actual suggestion or two thrown in here and there, I just canâ€™t help myself):

Girl

(1) Charis

I love this idea, it might be my favorite. Charis, which is said like Karis and Carys and is contained within the word Eucharist, means â€œgraceâ€! In fact, thatâ€™s what it means within the word Eucharist! (From Merriam-Webster: â€œfrom eucharistos grateful, from eu- + charizesthai to show favor, from charis favor, grace, gratitude; akin to Greek chairein to rejoice.â€) I know of a family who named their daughter Charis because of the Eucharist connection, and I really love it for a sister for Julia and Phoebe (itâ€™s got that different ending!). Both Julia and Phoebe have middle names that mean â€œgrace,â€ but I really like Charis as a first name for this baby. It can certainly work as a middle too, though I found it sort of difficult to work with rhythm-wise. If they prefer it in the middle, I think something with the rhythm of Felicity Charis would sound lovely.

(2) Margo(t)

Margaret didnâ€™t seem quite right to me, but I love its variant Margo(t)! It can take any of the Sts. Margaret as patron, and of course means the same as Margaret â€” â€œpearl,â€ which happens to be Juneâ€™s birthstone! Kind of a cool connection for a baby due in June!

(3) Maud(e)

When I saw Maud(e) in one of the recent Appellation Mountain posts, I was immediately struck by it. Iâ€™ve never, not once, considered or thought of the name Maud(e) for anyone, but for some reason, it really seemed like one Grace might like! Itâ€™s a variant of Matilda (in fact, itâ€™s Matildaâ€™s â€œusual medieval form,â€ like Austin for Augustine and Bennett for Benedict), which provides a patron saint.

(4) Edith, Esther

Both Edith and Esther have a similar feel to me â€” names that were too old lady-ish for a baby not that long ago, but that Iâ€™m starting to see on little girls more and more. St. Edith Stein is a huge inspiration behind the little Catholic girls I see with the name (sheâ€™s amazing), and I love that Esther is biblical like Julia and Phoebe. Edie and Essie are both adorable nicknames too.

(5) Eliza

Iâ€™m not sure what to say about Eliza except that it feels like it might be right! I like it on its own for the Pattons (so far theyâ€™ve done shorter girl names [letter-wise] while tending toward longer boy names), but I also like it as a nickname for Elizabeth, if they preferred that.

(6) Bernadette, Colette

Grace and her girls recently took an amazing trip to France, so French names were on my mind when I was working on this. I decided that I really like Bernadette for them! Itâ€™s definitely an up-and-coming name vintage-y name, as we discussed recently on the blog, and it was also in my recent saintly nicknames post (which I submitted as my February CatholicMom article after incorporating your ideas from the comments). The spotlight I did on it a few years ago has a few nickname options too. I also love (LOVE) Colette â€¦ but maybe itâ€™s not quite right coming right after Clement? If thatâ€™s not a bother though, itâ€™s such a pretty name, and St. Colette is a great patron.

Before moving onto boy names, I want to discuss more fully Simonâ€™s hope that theyâ€™ll give a name that means â€œgraceâ€ to a girl. I searched on behindthename.com and also a general google search for names meaning â€œgrace,â€ and the results are almost all variants of Grace or contain Grace (like Graciela, Altagracia, and Engracia), or are variants of Anne (since Anne means â€œgraceâ€). Juliaâ€™s middle name nods to the former (being Grace), and Phoebeâ€™s to the latter (being Anika), which is another reason I was psyched to find Charis â€” itâ€™s in a third category altogether! Another thatâ€™s neither Grace nor Anne is Amara, which is Igbo (the language of the Igbo people of Nigeria) for â€œgrace,â€ and is quite pretty. Otherwise, I think an Anne name is the best bet, since there are a few that are different enough from Anika I think. Like:

Anja or Anya

Anna or Anne

Annabel(le)

Annette

Anouk

Hannah

Nan, Nancy, Nanette

(many others listed here)

If Grace and Simon like the idea of an Anne name, they might like to choose one based on how their chosen first name sounds. Margo Annabelle sounds gorgeous to me, for example, as does Charis Anne and Charis Annette, Maude Annette, Bernadette Anne, Edith Annabelle, Eliza Nanette â€¦ so many beautiful ways to put these names together!

Boy

(1) Oscar

Moving onto boy names, Iâ€™m seeing Oscar here and there a bit more these days â€” Iâ€™m thinking of it as a recent addition to the Owen, Oliver group (along with Otto). St. Oscar Romero is a great patron, and the inspiration behind the choice of name for this sweet boy.

(2) Vincent, Victor

Vincent and Victor are old school Catholicky Catholic names that I think always wear well. The full Vincent is so handsome, and Vince and Vinny are easy nicknames. Victor is a particular favorite of mine â€” I tried to convince my hubby of it many times, and I wrote a whole CatholicMom article about it. â€œNicknames for Victorâ€ also continues to be one of the most frequent search terms that lead people to my blog, because of this post I did. So fascinating!

(3) Raphael, Ralph

Iâ€™d previously suggested Gabriel for them, but since having Abe, Gabe is no longer an option. Raphaelâ€™s rarer anyway, and has the cool nickname Rafe. Speaking of Rafe, what do we think about Ralph? I donâ€™t hugely love the â€œralfâ€ pronunciation, but Iâ€™ve long loved that Rafe is a traditional pronunciation of it (and the one actor Ralph Fiennes uses). Cool? Or too high maintenance? (I remembered that I thought Design Mom has a Ralph, so I looked it up to be sure and hoooooly cow, check out Ralphâ€™s siblings: Maude, Olive, Oscar, Betty, and Flora June. !!! Iâ€™ve included Maude, Olive, and Oscar somewhere in this post [either as todayâ€™s predictions or previous consultation ideas]; Betty can totally be a nickname for Bernadette; and Iâ€™m not joking that I considered the Flora/Fleur/Florence idea before deciding not to include it here. Wow. Spot.On.) Iâ€™ve recently come to love St. Ralph Sherwin, which is another plus in Ralphâ€™s favor.

(4) Bear

This is another backing-into-a-name-from-a-nickname idea. Animal names â€” like Fox and Bear â€” are big right now, and I considered Bear myself as a nickname for Benedict Gerard â€” I thought that was so cute! And I already liked Benedict as an idea for another Patton boy. Arthur is another that Iâ€™ve seen people using Bear as a nickname for, since Arthur is said to have â€œbearâ€ as part of its meaning â€” Arthur has a very Design Mom feel to me, so maybe?

(5) JoaquÃ­n

Grace has a little Spanish flair to her style, as seen in sweet FelipÃ©â€™s name. JoaquÃ­n takes its cue from that, being the Spanish form of (my beloved) Joachim, and also the fact that itâ€™s not as unfamiliar as Joachim â€” Joaquin Phoenix and Kelly Ripaâ€™s son Joaquin are two examples of Joaquins that people might know (especially the former). (If they want to consider Joachim though, you know Iâ€™m all over that!!)

Those are all my predictions for boy names, but I couldnâ€™t resist offering this list of long, saintly names that Grace and Simon might consider for middle names (theyâ€™ve already used Xavier, Augustine, and Ignatius): Emmanuel, Thaddeus, Ambrose (ooh this might make a great first name for them?), Maximilian, Chrysostom, Athanasius, Matthias, and the once-considered Dominic and Damian.

And those are all the names that I think Patton Baby No. 8 might end up being given! What do you all think? Do you have any predictions or suggestions for the little brother or sister of Julia, Sebastian, Theodore, Phoebe, Bosco, Abraham, and Clement?

My book, Catholic Baby Names for Girls and Boys: Over 250 Ways to Honor Our Lady (Marian Press, 2018), is available to order from ShopMercy.org and Amazon â€” perfect for expectant parents, name enthusiasts, and lovers of Our Lady!

Happppppy Easter Monday yâ€™all!!! I hope you all had a wonderful weekend!!! Doesnâ€™t the world look extra sunny now that Lent is over and the tomb is empty? He is risen! Hallelujah!

Iâ€™m thrilled/delighted/dancing with joy ğŸ’ƒğŸ’ƒğŸ’ƒ to post todayâ€™s consultation! Funny enough, it was Easter Monday of 2015 when I posted the first consultation I did for this family (for Baby No. 5) â€” pretty cool that I get to post one for their newest little one on Easter Monday 2017!

So yes, as youâ€™ve surely gleaned from the title, todayâ€™s consultation is for Grace over at Camp Patton â€” sheâ€™s one of my favorite favorite bloggers, not least because she posts lots of pictures of her beautiful children, and she are her husband have the BEST taste in names! Lest youâ€™ve forgotten, this wee green bean (=gender unknown) ğŸŒ± will join big sibs:

Julia Grace

Sebastian Xavier (Bash)

Theodore Augustine (Theo)

Phoebe Annika

Bosco Ignatius

(In calling this baby No. 6, I mean their sixth baby on earth â€” I donâ€™t at all mean to forget their little Felipe, whoâ€™s surely interceding for them all, like so many of our babies.)

Iâ€™m ridiculously in love with the names Grace and her hubby Simon have chosen, and thereâ€™s not really a whole lot I feel like I can add â€” no matter what they end up naming their babe, I know it will be ah-mazing.

That said, when I asked Grace if she would mind if I offered some new suggestions, she said:

â€œYes! Weâ€™d love that!

We are always so undecided until the last minute!

Thank you Kate!!!! SO excited!!!â€œ

I know, right?? SO EXCITED!! ğŸ˜ğŸ˜ğŸ˜

She continued,

â€œFor boys weâ€™ve tossed around Dominic or Damian (I think we should avoid a name ending in â€œoâ€ as weâ€™ve got Theo, Bosco, and now Diego and Iâ€™m constantly confusing their names!) and for girls I kind of like Caroline or Felicity but Iâ€™m not sure if Felicity is too similar to Phoebe and if itâ€™s too long a name not to have a nickname for? (Iâ€™m not a huge fan of â€œlissyâ€) â€” I suggested Simon for a boy but Simon said that ship has sailed since we didnâ€™t name our first born Simon but I disagree â€” ha!!!â€œ

As Iâ€™m sure youâ€™re not surprised by, I have thoughts about this whole paragraph. First, I LOVE Dominic and Damian. Love! Dominicâ€™s one of my very favorites (I spotlighted the name here), and Iâ€™m over the moon every time I see anyone considering Damian! (Hereâ€™s a little Damien I did a recent birth announcement for.) Itâ€™s such a great name with such a great saintly pedigree, I canâ€™t say enough good things about it. (Iâ€™m not even going to acknowledge that movie. And I really hope you donâ€™t know what Iâ€™m referring to.)

I also love Caroline and Felicity, both of which I included in my ideas in my first consultation post ğŸ˜Š. So letâ€™s talk about Felicity. (1) Do I think itâ€™s too similar to Phoebe? I do not. I considered this last time and decided it was perfect enough, even following immediately after Phoebe, to include it in my list of ideas. In a family with a bunch of kids, two of them sharing the same initial sound isnâ€™t that big a deal at all, especially with having different first initials. Add in that, this time, thereâ€™s a Bosco in between Phoebe and this new baby, and I think itâ€™s totally and completely fine. (2) What about nicknames? Nicknames! The nickname issue so often seems to be a sticking point in regards to choosing Felicity! But fear not â€” I did a spotlight on Felicity recently, and I included nickname ideas! A lot of the readers left great ideas too, including what they call their real-life little Felicitys, so be sure to check it out; some that I think could work well for the Pattons include:

Fliss(y)

Flick, Flicka (actress Felicity Huffman has a web site for women in general and moms in particular called What the Flicka)

Lily

Fin (especially maybe for something like Felicity Nora)

Zita is a Hungarian diminutive of the name, and Zyta a Polish short form

Felly

Cissy

Flitzi, Fitzi, Fitz

Cece

Liddy

So I would definitely keep Felicity on their list, and I know one little Felicity in real life who is always Felicity, so thatâ€™s an option too.

And what about Simon, after Dad? Iâ€™m glad brother Theodore isnâ€™t interfering with Graceâ€™s love of this idea, because Simon is a great name. But what about naming a non-firstborn son after dad? This could be the topic of a whole other post â€” in fact, Iâ€™ll plan to do that soon â€” but Iâ€™ll offer that though perhaps itâ€™s more traditional to name a firstborn son after dad, if youâ€™re going to do that kind of thing, itâ€™s not UNtraditional nor unheard of to give Dadâ€™s name to a subsequent son. Iâ€™ve got loads of personal examples: we named our firstborn after our two dads, and our second boy got my husbandâ€™s name as a middle, my brotherâ€™s second son is a Junior, my two brothers were named after my grandfathers, and if there was ever a third boy he would have gotten my dadâ€™s name as a middle. Thereâ€™s something really nice about naming a non-firstborn after Dad, actually â€” there are a lot of traditional firstborn â€œperks,â€ so saving Dadâ€™s name for a second/third/fourth son could help even the playing field a bit. But if Simon canâ€™t come around to the idea of Simon as a first name, I think it would make an amazing middle (for a boy or a girl! More on that below).

Really, I think Dominic, Damian, Simon, Caroline, and Felicity would all be amazing additions to the amazingly named Patton children, and Iâ€™d be thrilled if they named their baby any of them.

Despite the fact that the Patton Parents are expert namers and have some tremendous ideas, of course I can always come up with some more! First I just have to say, I still love all the ideas I suggested last time (for a girl: various ideas for backing into the nickname Lola, Elisabeth, Felicity, Stella; for a boy: Maximilian nicked Miles, Francis nicked Finn, Gregory nicked Rory or Gus [Gregory Simon=Gus so perfectly!]). And the arrival of Mr. Bosco opened up another whole area of possibilities with the last-name-as-first name thing, which really had already been there a little bit with Bashâ€™s middle name being Xavier (I think Xavierâ€™s mostly lost its last-naminess, but when thereâ€™s also a Bosco in the family, it comes to the fore a little more), so I was tempted to offer some more along those lines â€” Kolbe, Bennett, Becket, Siena, Serra â€” but I fought against it because I was feeling like following Bosco with another surname name might feel like a little too much. Do you agree? I did make two exceptions though, which Iâ€™ll explain below.

Okay! On to my ideas. You all know that I rely heavily on the Baby Name Wizard in my consultations, as it offers, for each entry, boy and girl names that are similar in terms of style/feel/popularity, and I also used Nymbler and the Name Matchmaker this time around as well. I used both the names theyâ€™ve already used (first names only, except I also included Xavier and Annika, both of which Grace has said in the past that she sort of wished theyâ€™d saved for first names), and those theyâ€™re considering in my research. A lot of names spoke to me that didnâ€™t last time, and I also took some chances and ventured farther afield. This is what I came up with:

Girl

(1) Emmeline

I started out feeling like the Pattons had a Brideshead Revisisted feel going on with Julia, Sebastian, and Theodore, and while I initially felt a little bit like Phoebe threw me for a loop, all I had to do was remember that my own family tree on my dadâ€™s side â€” which has a direct line back to 1600s England â€” has a bunch of girls named Phebe in it (that spelling), especially the closer you get to the familyâ€™s emigration from England, to make me think I wasnâ€™t that far off with Brideshead Revisited. Add in Caroline and Felicity to the names theyâ€™re considering, and Iâ€™m feeling pretty good about suggesting the lovely Emmeline. Behind the Name says itâ€™s a variant of Amelia, which is where patron saints can be found, or you could think of it as an elaboration of Emma, in which case these saints would suit. It can be said emma-LINE, emma-LYNN, and emma-LEEN, and can be spelled Emmaline and Emmalyn. Emma and Emmy are sweet nicknames.

(2) Magdalene

This is the first surname name I allowed myself to suggest, both because itâ€™s a girlâ€™s name rather than a boyâ€™s, and because it doesnâ€™t feel surnamey and has a long history of use as a first name. I also like that itâ€™s long, like Sebastian and Theodore â€” until now the girlsâ€™ names have been short, and until Bosco the boysâ€™ names were long, so itâ€™s kind of cool to switch it up with a longer girlâ€™s name. There are lots of nickname possibilities: Maggie, Maddie, Molly, and Magda are some that Iâ€™d consider (Magda has that Brit feel to me).

(3) Verity

Ever since watching Poldark (which I happen to know Grace is a little bit into), Iâ€™ve loved the name Verity. Not only is it uncommon but familiar, which is sort of a sweet spot with naming, itâ€™s got great faith significance in the sense that it means â€œtruth.â€ It also has a little of that Puritan feeling that I get from Phoebe and Felicity, which is a feel I love.

(4) Audrey

I was surprised to find Audrey listed as style match for Dominic, so I looked it up in the BNW and a good number of the names listed as similar to it are ones I could see fitting in really well at Camp Patton, like Claire, Evelyn, Charlotte, Elliott, and Luke. I thought about it for a bit, and since Audrey Hepburn is its overwhelming association for me, and she herself was British (not to keep harping on the British thing), I started to really feel it. Itâ€™s classy, and literary (Shakespearean, no less: As You Like It), and saintly (though it took me a few minutes to find a version of her story that was uplifting).

(5) Mary/Maria + _____

I mentioned the possibility of a Mary+ name in my last consultation, and itâ€™s on the list again! Iâ€™m a big fan of balance in baby naming, which I realize works better on storybook families than those in the real world, and itâ€™s so totally not a big deal whether sibling names have that aesthetic composition that makes me sigh with contentment, but as many of you know I do often find myself trying to come up with names that â€œbridgeâ€ different styles in the names of the already-born children. With Boscoâ€™s name having a different feel than his big sibs, I wanted to offer an idea that might make sense of it beyond the [very real and awesome] â€œCatholic names all go together by virtue of them being Catholic namesâ€ idea (which I myself have happily employed in the naming of my own children). To that end, I thought a Mary+ double would be just the thing, as putting Mary in front of virtually any name makes it (1) totally doable for a girl and (2) gives it a Catholic oomph, and (3) thereâ€™s the added layer of a double first name being unusual enough that it can fit in with all sorts of unusual names. There were a few ideas I liked for this idea (and I liked Maria as much as or better than Mary in some examples):

Mary Simone or Maria Simone: I mentioned above that if Dad Patton canâ€™t get on board with Simon for a boyâ€™s first, maybe he wouldnâ€™t mind it as a middle for a boy OR a girl. I really love the idea of Mary Simone or Maria Simone, *especially* if a nickname like Maisie is used! You know Iâ€™m a fan of those firstname+middlename mashup nicknames! I think Mary/Maria Simone nicked Maisie would be amazing. (And they could even go with the old English pronunciation of Maria if they wanted, which is like Mariah â€” I know a little girl who has Maria-pronounced-like-Mariah for a middle name.)

Mary Tess or Maria Tess: I like Tess for them anyway, but I donâ€™t feel like Therese/T(h)eresa is exactly their style. But Mary Tess or Maria Tess are sweet! She could go by the double name, or just Tess on the day-to-day.

Mary Elliott, or Mary Emmett, or Mary Bennett: One of my favorite things to do with a Mary+ double is to pair it with a boy name or a surname (this is my second surname suggestion). It feminizes the second name without making it seem like a girl name, if that makes any sense, and gives the very Catholic & traditional Mary+ construction a little whimsy and unexpectedness while still staying grounded. Elliott, Emmett, and Bennett are all names I liked for them for a boy, but ultimately cut them from my final list â€” this would be a neat way to work them in in a different way. (Elliott is a variant of Elijah, Emmett is actually from a surname deriving from Emma, and Bennett is a medieval variant of Benedict, so lots of patron saint options here.)

A last note about girl names: There were several that I considered last time that didnâ€™t make the cut then or now, including Penelope, Imogen(e), Genevieve, Iris or Ivy, Lydia, Corinne, and Liv. This time around, the ones that I considered but ultimately decided not to include on this girl list include Alice, Zara, Lydia (for the second time â€¦ hmmm), and Natalia.

Boy

(1) Oliver

I honestly donâ€™t know why I didnâ€™t suggest Oliver last time â€” I love it for the Pattons!! It did tremendously well in my research, being similar to Julia, Sebastian, Phoebe, Felicity, and Simon. Wow! In this consultation from a couple months ago, a family (who already has a Dominic and a Kolbe â€” like Dominic on the Pattonsâ€™ list and Kolbe has a similar feel to Bosco to me) who was considering Oliver explained, â€œWe like Oliver Plunkettâ€™s story because in todayâ€™s culture it is hard to be a faithful Catholic. Weâ€™d like any name-sake to be an example of how to live out the faith when facing persecution or other challengesâ€ â€” I love that! Additionally, though it seems that Oliver is not etymologically related to â€œolive,â€ itâ€™s close enough that it could be a nod to Our Lady of the Olives, and you all know what a sucker I am for a Marian boy name! A reader also pointed this out to me from Psalm 128:

â€œYour wife will be like a fruitful vine

within your home,

Your children like young olive plants

around your table.â€

Um, pretty accurate Iâ€™d say (in the very very best way!). ğŸ˜‰ In that same consultation, I also suggested middle names for Oliver and I thought some of the combos might appeal to the Pattons as well: Oliver Nathaniel, Oliver James, Oliver Matthias.

(2) Isaac

Isaac has been on my own list for a long time, I love it! I love that itâ€™s biblical, which Iâ€™m sure itâ€™s why it was listed as a style match for Julia and Phoebe, and I love that itâ€™s saintly â€” St. Isaac Jogues is one of the North American Martyrs (their shrine is near me and a local church is named after him, so the name really has taken on more of a saintly feel than biblical for me). Itâ€™s got great nickname options in Ike and Zac.

(3) Gabriel

Gabriel is a fantastic name for a little boy. Itâ€™s biblical, saintly, angelic, and Marian, which covers all the bases! Itâ€™s a style match for Xavier, Simon, Dominic, and has great nickname options: Gabe is friendly and boyish; Gil is bookish and dreamy in a Gilbert Blythe sort of way.

(4) Alexander

Alexander is a long name name like Sebastian and Theodore; itâ€™s papal and saintly and pan-European; but what really encouraged me to put it on the list was the nickname Xander. (5) Nathaniel
